elements.content: As an important basic raw material, ethylene (C2H4) has been widely utilized as basic raw materials for some important industrial products such as plastics, rubber and acetic acid. As a commonly used C2H4 production procedure, steam cracking of petroleum or natural gas also generates a small amount of C2H2 (ca. 1%) as an impurity. To obtain highly pure C2H4 for the preparation of these materials, the separation of acetylene (C2H2) from the mixture with C2H4 is a pivotal industrial process. Compared to traditional separation methods, such as C2H2 hydrogenation, cryogenic distillation and oil-adsorption, the adsorption-based selective separation on the porous materials under ambient conditions might be more energy and cost efficient.
elements.clean_text: As an important basic raw material, ethylene (C2H4) has been widely utilized as basic raw materials for some important industrial products such as plastics, rubber and acetic acid. As a commonly used C2H4 production procedure, steam cracking of petroleum or natural gas also generates a small amount of C2H2 (ca. 1%) as an impurity. To obtain highly pure C2H4 for the preparation of these materials, the separation of acetylene (C2H2) from the mixture with C2H4 is a pivotal industrial process. Compared to traditional separation methods, such as C2H2 hydrogenation, cryogenic distillation and oil-adsorption, the adsorption-based selective separation on the porous materials under ambient conditions might be more energy and cost efficient.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as an important class of organic–inorganic hybrid microporous materials, might provide an alternative approach for C2H2 capture from C2H4 under ambient conditions, which was witnessed by recent significant progresses in C2H2/C2H4 separation. For example, Chen and co-workers reported a series of MOFs, including M′MOFs, UTSA-100a and UTSA-200a, which exhibit highly efficient C2H2/C2H4 separation. NOTT-300, which was reported by Schröder and co-workers, also exhibits high affinity to acetylene in binding competition between acetylene and other C2 hydrocarbons. In addition, Long and co-workers reported that Fe-MOF-74 with open metal sites is also capable of selectively adsorbing C2H2 over other C1–C2 hydrocarbons. More recently, Xing, Zaworotko and Chen reported the “SIFSIX” materials as new benchmarks for the selective capture of C2H2 from C2H4, where the SiF6 2– anion provides the preferential binding sites for C2H2 molecules.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as an important class of organic-inorganic hybrid microporous materials, might provide an alternative approach for C2H2 capture from C2H4 under ambient conditions, which was witnessed by recent significant progresses in C2H2/C2H4 separation. For example, Chen and co-workers reported a series of MOFs, including M'MOFs, UTSA-100a and UTSA-200a, which exhibit highly efficient C2H2/C2H4 separation. NOTT-300, which was reported by Schröder and co-workers, also exhibits high affinity to acetylene in binding competition between acetylene and other C2 hydrocarbons. In addition, Long and co-workers reported that Fe-MOF-74 with open metal sites is also capable of selectively adsorbing C2H2 over other C1-C2 hydrocarbons. More recently, Xing, Zaworotko and Chen reported the "SIFSIX" materials as new benchmarks for the selective capture of C2H2 from C2H4, where the SiF6 2- anion provides the preferential binding sites for C2H2 molecules.

elements.content: Currently, the C2H2 adsorption study mainly focuses on its isotherm measurements for the information on overall gas adsorption and selectivity. In contrast, the detailed study of C2H2 adsorption mechanism on MOFs, especially by single crystal X-ray diffraction, is extremely limited. As we know, it is not easy to get stable C2H2⊂MOF single-crystals under ambient conditions. Although this study is technically challenging, it would greatly deepen our understanding of the detailed selective adsorption mechanism at the molecular level and , moreover, provide detailed structural information for the design of new technologically MOF-based adsorbents.
elements.clean_text: Currently, the C2H2 adsorption study mainly focuses on its isotherm measurements for the information on overall gas adsorption and selectivity. In contrast, the detailed study of C2H2 adsorption mechanism on MOFs, especially by single crystal X-ray diffraction, is extremely limited. As we know, it is not easy to get stable C2H2⊂MOF single-crystals under ambient conditions. Although this study is technically challenging, it would greatly deepen our understanding of the detailed selective adsorption mechanism at the molecular level and , moreover, provide detailed structural information for the design of new technologically MOF-based adsorbents.

elements.content: Recently, we reported a highly stable 3D Cd­(II)-triazole MOF ([Cd­(L)2(ClO4)2]·H2O (1), L = 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl-3-phenyl)-1,2,4-triazole), which contains square-like channels (ca. 11 Å × 11 Å). Luckily, when the single crystals of 1 were activated at 403 K for 3 h and then exposed to C2H2 gas in a sealed vial (r.t., 1 atm), a new host–guest system with encapsulated C2H2 molecules C2H2⊂APPT-Cd-ClO4 – (2), were obtained via single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation, as shown in a. 2 crystallizes in a tetragonal crystal system with P43212 space group, which is the same as that of 1. Comparison of the structures of 1 and 2 shows almost no change for their frameworks except the encapsulated guest molecules (selected bonds and angles are listed in Table S2, Supporting Information (SI)). As indicated in b, the C2H2 molecule is bound to the disordered ClO4 – anion through two sets of weak C–H···O hydrogen bonds (d (O···H) = 2.248(16)–2.907(6) Å). This soft supramolecular interaction fixes the weakly acidic C2H2 molecules in the channels along the crystallographic c axis, leading to the efficient packing of 1.4 C2H2 molecules per CdL2 unit. Besides single-crystal analysis, room temperature 1H NMR (see SI, Figure S1) performed on the single-crystals of 2 also clearly showed that the existence of the C2H2 guest in 2. The C2H2 proton resonance appeared at δ = 2.85 ppm with the integral area corresponding to the uptake amount of 1.4 C2H2 molecules per CdL2 unit (by reference to −NH2 group on the ligand), which is well consistent with that of single-crystal analysis. This room temperature C2H2 uptake by 1 was further evidenced by the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (SI, Figure S1).
elements.clean_text: Recently, we reported a highly stable 3D Cd(II)-triazole MOF ([Cd(L)2(ClO4)2]⋅H2O (1), L = 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl-3-phenyl)-1,2,4-triazole), which contains square-like channels (ca. 11 Å × 11 Å). Luckily, when the single crystals of 1 were activated at 403 K for 3 h and then exposed to C2H2 gas in a sealed vial (r.t., 1 atm), a new host-guest system with encapsulated C2H2 molecules C2H2⊂APPT-Cd-ClO4 - (2), were obtained via single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation, as shown in a. 2 crystallizes in a tetragonal crystal system with P43212 space group, which is the same as that of 1. Comparison of the structures of 1 and 2 shows almost no change for their frameworks except the encapsulated guest molecules (selected bonds and angles are listed in Table S2, Supporting Information (SI)). As indicated in b, the C2H2 molecule is bound to the disordered ClO4 - anion through two sets of weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (d (O⋅⋅⋅H) = 2.248(16)-2.907(6) Å). This soft supramolecular interaction fixes the weakly acidic C2H2 molecules in the channels along the crystallographic c axis, leading to the efficient packing of 1.4 C2H2 molecules per CdL2 unit. Besides single-crystal analysis, room temperature 1H NMR (see SI, Figure S1) performed on the single-crystals of 2 also clearly showed that the existence of the C2H2 guest in 2. The C2H2 proton resonance appeared at δ = 2.85 ppm with the integral area corresponding to the uptake amount of 1.4 C2H2 molecules per CdL2 unit (by reference to -NH2 group on the ligand), which is well consistent with that of single-crystal analysis. This room temperature C2H2 uptake by 1 was further evidenced by the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (SI, Figure S1).

elements.content: (a) Adsorption of C2H2 in the 1D channel of APPT-Cd MOF, and single crystal structure of 2 (encapsulated C2H2 shown as space-filling model). (b) C–H···O hydrogen bonding system (shown as dotted line) in 2.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Adsorption of C2H2 in the 1D channel of APPT-Cd MOF, and single crystal structure of 2 (encapsulated C2H2 shown as space-filling model). (b) C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding system (shown as dotted line) in 2.

elements.content: On the other hand, the C2H2 adsorption/desorption based on 1 at room temperature is reversible, which was monitored by the room temperature 1H NMR spectra. As shown in , when the crystals of 2 were allowed to stand at room temperature in air, the C2H2 loading amount in 2 gradually decreased as the time went on, and it basically escaped from the framework after 5 h. Thus, 1 herein is a reusable dynamic-based MOF framework for C2H2 uptake under ambient conditions. Notably, the C2H2 release on 1 is temperature-dependent. The 1H NMR spectra of 2 at 0 °C (SI, Figure S5) showed that C2H2 release from Cd­(II)-MOF was much slower, and one-third amount of C2H2 still stayed in the framework after 20 h. This further implies that the host–guest interactions indeed exist.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the C2H2 adsorption/desorption based on 1 at room temperature is reversible, which was monitored by the room temperature 1H NMR spectra. As shown in , when the crystals of 2 were allowed to stand at room temperature in air, the C2H2 loading amount in 2 gradually decreased as the time went on, and it basically escaped from the framework after 5 h. Thus, 1 herein is a reusable dynamic-based MOF framework for C2H2 uptake under ambient conditions. Notably, the C2H2 release on 1 is temperature-dependent. The 1H NMR spectra of 2 at 0 °C (SI, Figure S5) showed that C2H2 release from Cd(II)-MOF was much slower, and one-third amount of C2H2 still stayed in the framework after 20 h. This further implies that the host-guest interactions indeed exist.

elements.content: 1H NMR spectra (DMSO-d 6) monitoring the desorption of C2H2 from 2 (top) and 4 (bottom) crystals at 298 K and 1 atm. The peak integrals for −NH2 group (δ = 6.50 ppm) was set as 1.00. For 2, the peak integrals for C2H2 (*, δ = 2.85 ppm) were 0.74 (0 h), 0.67 (1 h), 0.34 (2 h), 0.23 (3 h), 0.13 (4 h) and 0 (5 h), respectively, by reference to that of −NH2 groups. For 4, the peak integrals for C2H2 (*, δ = 2.85 ppm) were 0.74 (0 h), 0.31 (1 h), 0.25 (2 h) and 0.05 (3 h), respectively, by reference to that of −NH2 group on the ligand. The APPT-Cd MOF is soluble in DMSO, so the 1H NMR measurement was directly performed on the DMSO-d 6 solutions of the guest-loaded MOF crystals.
elements.clean_text: 2   1H NMR spectra (DMSO-d 6) monitoring the desorption of C2H2 from 2 (top) and 4 (bottom) crystals at 298 K and 1 atm. The peak integrals for -NH2 group (δ = 6.50 ppm) was set as 1.00. For 2, the peak integrals for C2H2 (*, δ = 2.85 ppm) were 0.74 (0 h), 0.67 (1 h), 0.34 (2 h), 0.23 (3 h), 0.13 (4 h) and 0 (5 h), respectively, by reference to that of -NH2 groups. For 4, the peak integrals for C2H2 (*, δ = 2.85 ppm) were 0.74 (0 h), 0.31 (1 h), 0.25 (2 h) and 0.05 (3 h), respectively, by reference to that of -NH2 group on the ligand. The APPT-Cd MOF is soluble in DMSO, so the 1H NMR measurement was directly performed on the DMSO-d 6 solutions of the guest-loaded MOF crystals.

elements.content: In contrast, when the activated single crystals of 1 were exposed to less acidic C2H4 gas under the same conditions, single-crystal analysis indicated no C2H4 species were found in the framework pores. The 1H NMR spectrum indicates that only tiny amount of C2H4 (δ = 5.42 ppm) captured, corresponding to 0.15 molecule per CdL2 (SI, Figure S4). So 1 herein exhibits the specific binding affinity for C2H2 over C2H4 at room temperature. Compared to C2H4, the more acidic C2H2 logically prefers to bind weakly basic ClO4 – anion to form C2H2···ClO4 – H-bonding system via C–H···O H-bonds, which is paramount for this high adsorption selectivity..
elements.clean_text: In contrast, when the activated single crystals of 1 were exposed to less acidic C2H4 gas under the same conditions, single-crystal analysis indicated no C2H4 species were found in the framework pores. The 1H NMR spectrum indicates that only tiny amount of C2H4 (δ = 5.42 ppm) captured, corresponding to 0.15 molecule per CdL2 (SI, Figure S4). So 1 herein exhibits the specific binding affinity for C2H2 over C2H4 at room temperature. Compared to C2H4, the more acidic C2H2 logically prefers to bind weakly basic ClO4 - anion to form C2H2⋅⋅⋅ClO4 - H-bonding system via C-H⋅⋅⋅O H-bonds, which is paramount for this high adsorption selectivity..

elements.content: Based on the single-crystal analysis, the uncoordinated ClO4 – anions in the framework should play a central role in this unique room temperature C2H2 uptake. For further confirming this anion-assisted selective gas uptake, Cd-APPT-BF4 – (3, [Cd­(L)2(BF4)2]·H2O) with BF4 – anions was used instead of 1 to perform the gas uptake under the same conditions. 3 also selectively adsorbed C2H2 over C2H4 under the same conditions. X-ray single-crystal analysis (Table S1 and Figure S3) indicated that new host–guest system C2H2⊂APPT-Cd-BF4 – (4) was generated via SCSC transformation after activated 3 soaked in C2H2 atmosphere at room temperature for 4 h.
elements.clean_text: Based on the single-crystal analysis, the uncoordinated ClO4 - anions in the framework should play a central role in this unique room temperature C2H2 uptake. For further confirming this anion-assisted selective gas uptake, Cd-APPT-BF4 - (3, [Cd(L)2(BF4)2]⋅H2O) with BF4 - anions was used instead of 1 to perform the gas uptake under the same conditions. 3 also selectively adsorbed C2H2 over C2H4 under the same conditions. X-ray single-crystal analysis (Table S1 and Figure S3) indicated that new host-guest system C2H2⊂APPT-Cd-BF4 - (4) was generated via SCSC transformation after activated 3 soaked in C2H2 atmosphere at room temperature for 4 h.

elements.content: As shown in , 4 is isostructural to 2, and the encapdulated C2H2 guests were stabilized in the 1D channels by the C–H···F hydrogen bonding ((d (F···H) = 2.480(17) – 2.640(48) Å). 3 showed much less affinity for C2H4 (SI, Figure S4), and no any C2H4 species was observed in the channels of 3 depending on the single-crystal analysis under the same conditions. The C2H2 desorption from 4 is much faster, which resulted from the weaker C2H2···BF4 – interactions. As depicted in , 1H NMR monitoring showed that around half amount of C2H2 escaped within 1 h, and almost no C2H2 could be detected in 3 h at room temperature. So the C2H2 uptake herein is an anion-dominated process, and the different C2H2-anion H-bonding interactions resulted in the different C2H2 retention time within the APPT-Cd framework.
elements.clean_text: As shown in , 4 is isostructural to 2, and the encapdulated C2H2 guests were stabilized in the 1D channels by the C-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonding ((d (F⋅⋅⋅H) = 2.480(17) - 2.640(48) Å). 3 showed much less affinity for C2H4 (SI, Figure S4), and no any C2H4 species was observed in the channels of 3 depending on the single-crystal analysis under the same conditions. The C2H2 desorption from 4 is much faster, which resulted from the weaker C2H2⋅⋅⋅BF4 - interactions. As depicted in , 1H NMR monitoring showed that around half amount of C2H2 escaped within 1 h, and almost no C2H2 could be detected in 3 h at room temperature. So the C2H2 uptake herein is an anion-dominated process, and the different C2H2-anion H-bonding interactions resulted in the different C2H2 retention time within the APPT-Cd framework.

elements.content: Single crystal structure of C2H2⊂APPT-Cd-BF4 – (4). The encapsulated C2H2 guest molecules are fixed in the pores by the C–H···F hydrogen bonding system (shown as dotted line).
elements.clean_text: 3  Single crystal structure of C2H2⊂APPT-Cd-BF4 - (4). The encapsulated C2H2 guest molecules are fixed in the pores by the C-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonding system (shown as dotted line).

elements.content: Compared to 3, we think that 1 could be a better MOF host for separation of C2H2 from C2H2/C2H4 mixture under ambient conditions. When the activated crystals (100 mg) of 1 were respectively combined with C2H4/C2H2 binary mixture at molar ratios of 1.1:1, 2.3:1 and 4.4:1 in the headspace vials (10 mL, total amount of C2H2/C2H4 mixture is 0.446 mmol) after 24 h, the corresponding molar ratios of C2H4/C2H2 in vials changed to 1.4:1, 4.0:1 and 6.9:1 respectively (determined by GC analysis, Figure S6 and Table S3 in SI). The molar ratios of C2H4/C2H2 captured in 1 are determined to be 1:24, 1:6 and 1:3, respectively, by the 1H NMR spectra performed on the resulted crystals (SI, Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: Compared to 3, we think that 1 could be a better MOF host for separation of C2H2 from C2H2/C2H4 mixture under ambient conditions. When the activated crystals (100 mg) of 1 were respectively combined with C2H4/C2H2 binary mixture at molar ratios of 1.1:1, 2.3:1 and 4.4:1 in the headspace vials (10 mL, total amount of C2H2/C2H4 mixture is 0.446 mmol) after 24 h, the corresponding molar ratios of C2H4/C2H2 in vials changed to 1.4:1, 4.0:1 and 6.9:1 respectively (determined by GC analysis, Figure S6 and Table S3 in SI). The molar ratios of C2H4/C2H2 captured in 1 are determined to be 1:24, 1:6 and 1:3, respectively, by the 1H NMR spectra performed on the resulted crystals (SI, Figure S7).

elements.content: Encouraged by the obtained results, we further test the performance of 1 in the removal of a small amount of C2H2 from the C2H2/C2H4 binary mixture. As mentioned, the removal of C2H2 from C2H2/C2H4 mixture containing ca. 1% C2H2 is very significant, especially under ambient consitions. When the activated crystals of 1 (100 mg) was in a headspace vial (10 mL) which was filled with C2H4/C2H2 mixture at a molar ratio of 98.79:1.21 at room temperature, the static headspace gas chromatograpy (HS-GC, Figure S9 and Table S5 in SI) analysis on the gas mixture indicated that the C2H2 amount significantly decreased as the time went on. As shown in , the molar percentage of C2H2 in the gas mixture was rapidly down to 0.60% in 1 h. After 4 h, no more changes for the C2H2 amount in the mixture have been detected, and its molar percentage was eventually down to 0.04%, indicating the C2H2 loading equilibrium by 1 was reached. Thus, ca. 97% of C2H2 was successfully removed by 1 from ca. 1:99 C2H2/C2H4 binary mixture under ambinet conditions; consequently, the C2H4 purity is up to 99.96%.

When the activated crystals of 1 (100 mg) was in a headspace vial (10 mL) which was filled with C2H4/C2H2 mixture at a molar ratio of 98.79:1.21 at room temperature, the static headspace gas chromatograpy (HS-GC, Figure S9 and Table S5 in SI) analysis on the gas mixture indicated that the C2H2 amount significantly decreased as the time went on. As shown in , the molar percentage of C2H2 in the gas mixture was rapidly down to 0.60% in 1 h. After 4 h, no more changes for the C2H2 amount in the mixture have been detected, and its molar percentage was eventually down to 0.04%, indicating the C2H2 loading equilibrium by 1 was reached. Thus, ca. 97% of C2H2 was successfully removed by 1 from ca. 1:99 C2H2/C2H4 binary mixture under ambinet conditions; consequently, the C2H4 purity is up to 99.96%.

elements.content: Molar percentage of C2H4 and C2H2 in the C2H4/C2H2 (molar ratio, 98.79:1.21) binary mixture at different time over 1 based on HS-GC peak area (see SI).
elements.clean_text: 4  Molar percentage of C2H4 and C2H2 in the C2H4/C2H2 (molar ratio, 98.79:1.21) binary mixture at different time over 1 based on HS-GC peak area (see SI).

elements.content: For exploring the overall gas adsorption and selectivity of 1, the adsorption isotherms for C2H2 and C2H4 was examined on the activated samples based on virial-type equation, respectively. At 298 K and 1 atm, the C2H2 and C2H4 uptake amounts of 1 are 39.3 and 9.8 cm3 g–1, respectively (a). The corresponding C2H2/C2H4 uptake ratio is 4.01, which is much higher than that of UTSA-100a, NOTT-300, MOF-74 series and UTSA-67a except M′MOF-3a and Mn­(II)–Mn­(III)–MOF. As shown in b, 1 exhibits higher C2H2 uptake capacity (48.6 cm3 g–1) at 273 K, whereas the C2H4 uptake amount (9.7 cm3 g–1) is comparable to that at 298 K. The C2H2/C2H4 uptake ratio correspondingly increases to 5.01. The C2H2 adsorption on 1 is closely correlated with the temperature, further demonstrating the existence of the adsorbate–adsorbent interactions between C2H2 and APPT-Cd-ClO4 –, as revealed by the single crystal X-ray diffraction. Therefore, 1 herein exhibits a moderate C2H2 uptake, but shows a much lower uptake amount of C2H4, suggesting that the activated 1 could be a useful adsorption-based porous material for the C2H2/C2H4 separation under ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: For exploring the overall gas adsorption and selectivity of 1, the adsorption isotherms for C2H2 and C2H4 was examined on the activated samples based on virial-type equation, respectively. At 298 K and 1 atm, the C2H2 and C2H4 uptake amounts of 1 are 39.3 and 9.8 cm3 g-1, respectively (a). The corresponding C2H2/C2H4 uptake ratio is 4.01, which is much higher than that of UTSA-100a, NOTT-300, MOF-74 series and UTSA-67a except M'MOF-3a and Mn(II)-Mn(III)-MOF. As shown in b, 1 exhibits higher C2H2 uptake capacity (48.6 cm3 g-1) at 273 K, whereas the C2H4 uptake amount (9.7 cm3 g-1) is comparable to that at 298 K. The C2H2/C2H4 uptake ratio correspondingly increases to 5.01. The C2H2 adsorption on 1 is closely correlated with the temperature, further demonstrating the existence of the adsorbate-adsorbent interactions between C2H2 and APPT-Cd-ClO4 -, as revealed by the single crystal X-ray diffraction. Therefore, 1 herein exhibits a moderate C2H2 uptake, but shows a much lower uptake amount of C2H4, suggesting that the activated 1 could be a useful adsorption-based porous material for the C2H2/C2H4 separation under ambient conditions.

elements.content: (a) C2H2 (red) and C2H4 (blue) sorption isotherms on the activated 1 at 298 K. (b) C2H2 (red) and C2H4 (blue) sorption isotherms on the activated 1 at 273 K. Adsorption and desorption branches are shown with closed and open symbols, respectively. IAST calculations for binary C2H2/C2H4 mixture at ratios of 50:50 (black line) and 1:99 (red line) on 1 at 298 K (c) and 273 K (d), respectively.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) C2H2 (red) and C2H4 (blue) sorption isotherms on the activated 1 at 298 K. (b) C2H2 (red) and C2H4 (blue) sorption isotherms on the activated 1 at 273 K. Adsorption and desorption branches are shown with closed and open symbols, respectively. IAST calculations for binary C2H2/C2H4 mixture at ratios of 50:50 (black line) and 1:99 (red line) on 1 at 298 K (c) and 273 K (d), respectively.

elements.content: To predict the selective C2H2 separation performance over C2H4, the selectivity for 1:99 and 50:50 C2H2/C2H4 binary mixtures was estimated up to 1 atm from the single-component gas-adsorption isotherms utilizing ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) at 298 and 273 K, respectively. c shows the adsorption selectivity of the C2H2/C2H4 mixture containing 1% and 50% C2H2 as a function of total bulk gas phase pressure on 1 at 298 K. It can be seen that the adsorption selectivity of 1 for 1:99 C2H2/C2H4 mixture lies in the range of 9.1–14.7. This value is better than those of UTSA-100a (5–10.7), SIFSIX-1-Cu (7.1–10.6) and almost seven times higher than those obtained for NOTT-300 and MOF-74 series, but lower than those of SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (39.7–44.8), FJU-22a (25.8) and M′MOF-3a (24.03). (detailed comparison, see Table S6, Supporting Information). For 50:50 C2H2/C2H4 mixture, 1 exhibits higher selectivities (10.2–16.0) at 298 K. These selectivity values are lower than that of headspace adsorption experiments (selectivity 24.67), which might be caused by the different measuring conditions. As indicated in d, the IAST selectivities at 273 K are remarkably high, and they are up to 36.7–51.5 and 33.6–45.8 for the 1:99 and 50:50 C2H2/C2H4 binary mixtures, respectively.
elements.clean_text: To predict the selective C2H2 separation performance over C2H4, the selectivity for 1:99 and 50:50 C2H2/C2H4 binary mixtures was estimated up to 1 atm from the single-component gas-adsorption isotherms utilizing ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) at 298 and 273 K, respectively. c shows the adsorption selectivity of the C2H2/C2H4 mixture containing 1% and 50% C2H2 as a function of total bulk gas phase pressure on 1 at 298 K. It can be seen that the adsorption selectivity of 1 for 1:99 C2H2/C2H4 mixture lies in the range of 9.1-14.7. This value is better than those of UTSA-100a (5-10.7), SIFSIX-1-Cu (7.1-10.6) and almost seven times higher than those obtained for NOTT-300 and MOF-74 series, but lower than those of SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (39.7-44.8), FJU-22a (25.8) and M'MOF-3a (24.03). (detailed comparison, see Table S6, Supporting Information). For 50:50 C2H2/C2H4 mixture, 1 exhibits higher selectivities (10.2-16.0) at 298 K. These selectivity values are lower than that of headspace adsorption experiments (selectivity 24.67), which might be caused by the different measuring conditions. As indicated in d, the IAST selectivities at 273 K are remarkably high, and they are up to 36.7-51.5 and 33.6-45.8 for the 1:99 and 50:50 C2H2/C2H4 binary mixtures, respectively.

elements.content: These findings are well in agreement with the calculated isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st, Figure S11 in SI) over the temperature range of 273–298 K. The Q st value for C2H2 in 1 initially decreases slightly from 28.5 to 27.2 kJ mol–1, and then, after loading of 0.8 mmol g–1, increases slowly to a higher value of 31.7 kJ mol–1. This implies a cooperative binding mechanism, probably the interguest interactions simultaneously exist besides guest–anion interaction. In contrast, the Q st value for C2H4 adsorption in 1 is significantly lower (from 3.7 to 0.9 kJ mol–1). This confirms the absence of strong C2H4–host and C2H4–C2H4 interactions, which accords with its lower uptake and the crystallographic study. Experimental column breakthrough curves for C2H2/C2H4 mixed gas containing 10% and 25% C2H2 over 1 were carried out to demonstrate the C2H2 selectivity over C2H4 (Figures S12 and S13), and the separation of C2H2/C2H4 mixture gases through a column packed with solid 1 can be efficiently achieved.
elements.clean_text: These findings are well in agreement with the calculated isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st, Figure S11 in SI) over the temperature range of 273-298 K. The Q st value for C2H2 in 1 initially decreases slightly from 28.5 to 27.2 kJ mol-1, and then, after loading of 0.8 mmol g-1, increases slowly to a higher value of 31.7 kJ mol-1. This implies a cooperative binding mechanism, probably the interguest interactions simultaneously exist besides guest-anion interaction. In contrast, the Q st value for C2H4 adsorption in 1 is significantly lower (from 3.7 to 0.9 kJ mol-1). This confirms the absence of strong C2H4-host and C2H4-C2H4 interactions, which accords with its lower uptake and the crystallographic study. Experimental column breakthrough curves for C2H2/C2H4 mixed gas containing 10% and 25% C2H2 over 1 were carried out to demonstrate the C2H2 selectivity over C2H4 (Figures S12 and S13), and the separation of C2H2/C2H4 mixture gases through a column packed with solid 1 can be efficiently achieved.

elements.content: In conlusion, we first prepared two 3D C2H2⊂APPT-Cd MOF supramolecular complexes, by SCSC transformation under ambient conditions. The selective C2H2 binding mechanism was well characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The specific affinity toward C2H2 over C2H4 is ascribed to the C–H···X (X = O and F) H-bonding interactions between C2H2 and counteranions. In addition, the room temperature C2H2/C2H4 separation at different molar ratios was tested on the APPT-Cd-ClO4 – (1) bulk crystals, and we found it is able to effectively separate C2H2 from C2H4 even at 1:99 molar ratio, which was further supported by means of isotherm measurements and IAST calculations. This work provides direct structural evidence on molecular-binding modes of C2H2 within the MOF host. The supramolecular interactions between the guests and appropriate counteranions help increase the uptake selecitvity of MOF-based materials. We expect it will also provide some guidance on the screening and design of new MOF materials for practical application in C2H2 storage and separation.
elements.clean_text: In conlusion, we first prepared two 3D C2H2⊂APPT-Cd MOF supramolecular complexes, by SCSC transformation under ambient conditions. The selective C2H2 binding mechanism was well characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The specific affinity toward C2H2 over C2H4 is ascribed to the C-H⋅⋅⋅X (X = O and F) H-bonding interactions between C2H2 and counteranions. In addition, the room temperature C2H2/C2H4 separation at different molar ratios was tested on the APPT-Cd-ClO4 - (1) bulk crystals, and we found it is able to effectively separate C2H2 from C2H4 even at 1:99 molar ratio, which was further supported by means of isotherm measurements and IAST calculations. This work provides direct structural evidence on molecular-binding modes of C2H2 within the MOF host. The supramolecular interactions between the guests and appropriate counteranions help increase the uptake selecitvity of MOF-based materials. We expect it will also provide some guidance on the screening and design of new MOF materials for practical application in C2H2 storage and separation.

cln_elements.content: (a) Adsorption of C2H2 in the 1D channel of APPT-Cd MOF, and single crystal structure of 2 (encapsulated C2H2 shown as space-filling model). (b) C–H···O hydrogen bonding system (shown as dotted line) in 2.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Adsorption of C2H2 in the 1D channel of APPT-Cd MOF, and single crystal structure of 2 (encapsulated C2H2 shown as space-filling model). (b) C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding system (shown as dotted line) in 2.

cln_elements.content: 1H NMR spectra (DMSO-d 6) monitoring the desorption of C2H2 from 2 (top) and 4 (bottom) crystals at 298 K and 1 atm. The peak integrals for −NH2 group (δ = 6.50 ppm) was set as 1.00. For 2, the peak integrals for C2H2 (*, δ = 2.85 ppm) were 0.74 (0 h), 0.67 (1 h), 0.34 (2 h), 0.23 (3 h), 0.13 (4 h) and 0 (5 h), respectively, by reference to that of −NH2 groups. For 4, the peak integrals for C2H2 (*, δ = 2.85 ppm) were 0.74 (0 h), 0.31 (1 h), 0.25 (2 h) and 0.05 (3 h), respectively, by reference to that of −NH2 group on the ligand. The APPT-Cd MOF is soluble in DMSO, so the 1H NMR measurement was directly performed on the DMSO-d 6 solutions of the guest-loaded MOF crystals.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2   1H NMR spectra (DMSO-d 6) monitoring the desorption of C2H2 from 2 (top) and 4 (bottom) crystals at 298 K and 1 atm. The peak integrals for -NH2 group (δ = 6.50 ppm) was set as 1.00. For 2, the peak integrals for C2H2 (*, δ = 2.85 ppm) were 0.74 (0 h), 0.67 (1 h), 0.34 (2 h), 0.23 (3 h), 0.13 (4 h) and 0 (5 h), respectively, by reference to that of -NH2 groups. For 4, the peak integrals for C2H2 (*, δ = 2.85 ppm) were 0.74 (0 h), 0.31 (1 h), 0.25 (2 h) and 0.05 (3 h), respectively, by reference to that of -NH2 group on the ligand. The APPT-Cd MOF is soluble in DMSO, so the 1H NMR measurement was directly performed on the DMSO-d 6 solutions of the guest-loaded MOF crystals.

metadata.title:
APPT-Cd MOF: Acetylene Adsorption Mechanism and Its
Highly Efficient Acetylene/Ethylene Separation at Room Temperature
